contents.value:
Makes names from other namespaces visible without writing the namespace prefix.

Names that are made available with `open` are visible within the current `section` or `namespace`
block. This makes referring to (type) definitions and theorems easier, but note that it can also
make [scoped instances], notations, and attributes from a different namespace available.

The `open` command can be used in a few different ways:

* `open Some.Namespace.Path1 Some.Namespace.Path2` makes all non-protected names in
  `Some.Namespace.Path1` and `Some.Namespace.Path2` available without the prefix, so that
  `Some.Namespace.Path1.x` and `Some.Namespace.Path2.y` can be referred to by writing only `x` and
  `y`.

* `open Some.Namespace.Path hiding def1 def2` opens all non-protected names in `Some.Namespace.Path`
  except `def1` and `def2`.

* `open Some.Namespace.Path (def1 def2)` only makes `Some.Namespace.Path.def1` and
  `Some.Namespace.Path.def2` available without the full prefix, so `Some.Namespace.Path.def3` would
  be unaffected.

  This works even if `def1` and `def2` are `protected`.

* `open Some.Namespace.Path renaming def1 → def1', def2 → def2'` same as `open Some.Namespace.Path
  (def1 def2)` but `def1`/`def2`'s names are changed to `def1'`/`def2'`.

  This works even if `def1` and `def2` are `protected`.

* `open scoped Some.Namespace.Path1 Some.Namespace.Path2` **only** opens [scoped instances],
  notations, and attributes from `Namespace1` and `Namespace2`; it does **not** make any other name
  available.

* `open <any of the open shapes above> in` makes the names `open`-ed visible only in the next
  command or expression.

[scoped instance]: https://lean-lang.org/theorem_proving_in_lean4/type_classes.html#scoped-instances
(Scoped instances in Theorem Proving in Lean)


## Examples

```lean
/-- SKI combinators https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SKI_combinator_calculus -/
namespace Combinator.Calculus
  def I (a : α) : α := a
  def K (a : α) : β → α := fun _ => a
  def S (x : α → β → γ) (y : α → β) (z : α) : γ := x z (y z)
end Combinator.Calculus

section
  -- open everything under `Combinator.Calculus`, *i.e.* `I`, `K` and `S`,
  -- until the section ends
  open Combinator.Calculus

  theorem SKx_eq_K : S K x = I := rfl
end

-- open everything under `Combinator.Calculus` only for the next command (the next `theorem`, here)
open Combinator.Calculus in
theorem SKx_eq_K' : S K x = I := rfl

section
  -- open only `S` and `K` under `Combinator.Calculus`
  open Combinator.Calculus (S K)

  theorem SKxy_eq_y : S K x y = y := rfl

  -- `I` is not in scope, we have to use its full path
  theorem SKxy_eq_Iy : S K x y = Combinator.Calculus.I y := rfl
end

section
  open Combinator.Calculus
    renaming
      I → identity,
      K → konstant

  #check identity
  #check konstant
end

section
  open Combinator.Calculus
    hiding S

  #check I
  #check K
end

section
  namespace Demo
    inductive MyType
    | val

    namespace N1
      scoped infix:68 " ≋ " => BEq.beq

      scoped instance : BEq MyType where
        beq _ _ := true

      def Alias := MyType
    end N1
  end Demo

  -- bring `≋` and the instance in scope, but not `Alias`
  open scoped Demo.N1

  #check Demo.MyType.val == Demo.MyType.val
  #check Demo.MyType.val ≋ Demo.MyType.val
  -- #check Alias -- unknown identifier 'Alias'
end
```

Makes names from other namespaces visible without writing the namespace prefix.

Names that are made available with `open` are visible within the current `section` or `namespace`
block. This makes referring to (type) definitions and theorems easier, but note that it can also
make [scoped instances], notations, and attributes from a different namespace available.

The `open` command can be used in a few different ways:

* `open Some.Namespace.Path1 Some.Namespace.Path2` makes all non-protected names in
  `Some.Namespace.Path1` and `Some.Namespace.Path2` available without the prefix, so that
  `Some.Namespace.Path1.x` and `Some.Namespace.Path2.y` can be referred to by writing only `x` and
  `y`.

* `open Some.Namespace.Path hiding def1 def2` opens all non-protected names in `Some.Namespace.Path`
  except `def1` and `def2`.

* `open Some.Namespace.Path (def1 def2)` only makes `Some.Namespace.Path.def1` and
  `Some.Namespace.Path.def2` available without the full prefix, so `Some.Namespace.Path.def3` would
  be unaffected.

  This works even if `def1` and `def2` are `protected`.

* `open Some.Namespace.Path renaming def1 → def1', def2 → def2'` same as `open Some.Namespace.Path
  (def1 def2)` but `def1`/`def2`'s names are changed to `def1'`/`def2'`.

  This works even if `def1` and `def2` are `protected`.

* `open scoped Some.Namespace.Path1 Some.Namespace.Path2` **only** opens [scoped instances],
  notations, and attributes from `Namespace1` and `Namespace2`; it does **not** make any other name
  available.

* `open <any of the open shapes above> in` makes the names `open`-ed visible only in the next
  command or expression.

[scoped instance]: https://lean-lang.org/theorem_proving_in_lean4/type_classes.html#scoped-instances
(Scoped instances in Theorem Proving in Lean)


## Examples

```lean
/-- SKI combinators https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SKI_combinator_calculus -/
namespace Combinator.Calculus
  def I (a : α) : α := a
  def K (a : α) : β → α := fun _ => a
  def S (x : α → β → γ) (y : α → β) (z : α) : γ := x z (y z)
end Combinator.Calculus

section
  -- open everything under `Combinator.Calculus`, *i.e.* `I`, `K` and `S`,
  -- until the section ends

  theorem SKx_eq_K : S K x = I := rfl
end

-- open everything under `Combinator.Calculus` only for the next command (the next `theorem`, here)
open Combinator.Calculus in
theorem SKx_eq_K' : S K x = I := rfl

section
  -- open only `S` and `K` under `Combinator.Calculus`
  open Combinator.Calculus (S K)

  theorem SKxy_eq_y : S K x y = y := rfl

  -- `I` is not in scope, we have to use its full path
  theorem SKxy_eq_Iy : S K x y = Combinator.Calculus.I y := rfl
end

section
  open Combinator.Calculus
    renaming
      I → identity,
      K → konstant

  #check identity
  #check konstant
end

section
  open Combinator.Calculus
    hiding S

  #check I
  #check K
end

section
  namespace Demo
    inductive MyType
    | val

    namespace N1
      scoped infix:68 " ≋ " => BEq.beq

      scoped instance : BEq MyType where
        beq _ _ := true

      def Alias := MyType
    end N1
  end Demo

  -- bring `≋` and the instance in scope, but not `Alias`
  open scoped Demo.N1

  #check Demo.MyType.val == Demo.MyType.val
  #check Demo.MyType.val ≋ Demo.MyType.val
  -- #check Alias -- unknown identifier 'Alias'
end
```

Makes names from other namespaces visible without writing the namespace prefix.

Names that are made available with `open` are visible within the current `section` or `namespace`
block. This makes referring to (type) definitions and theorems easier, but note that it can also
make [scoped instances], notations, and attributes from a different namespace available.

The `open` command can be used in a few different ways:

* `open Some.Namespace.Path1 Some.Namespace.Path2` makes all non-protected names in
  `Some.Namespace.Path1` and `Some.Namespace.Path2` available without the prefix, so that
  `Some.Namespace.Path1.x` and `Some.Namespace.Path2.y` can be referred to by writing only `x` and
  `y`.

* `open Some.Namespace.Path hiding def1 def2` opens all non-protected names in `Some.Namespace.Path`
  except `def1` and `def2`.

* `open Some.Namespace.Path (def1 def2)` only makes `Some.Namespace.Path.def1` and
  `Some.Namespace.Path.def2` available without the full prefix, so `Some.Namespace.Path.def3` would
  be unaffected.

  This works even if `def1` and `def2` are `protected`.

* `open Some.Namespace.Path renaming def1 → def1', def2 → def2'` same as `open Some.Namespace.Path
  (def1 def2)` but `def1`/`def2`'s names are changed to `def1'`/`def2'`.

  This works even if `def1` and `def2` are `protected`.

* `open scoped Some.Namespace.Path1 Some.Namespace.Path2` **only** opens [scoped instances],
  notations, and attributes from `Namespace1` and `Namespace2`; it does **not** make any other name
  available.

* `open <any of the open shapes above> in` makes the names `open`-ed visible only in the next
  command or expression.

[scoped instance]: https://lean-lang.org/theorem_proving_in_lean4/type_classes.html#scoped-instances
(Scoped instances in Theorem Proving in Lean)

Makes names from other namespaces visible without writing the namespace prefix.

Names that are made available with `open` are visible within the current `section` or `namespace`
block. This makes referring to (type) definitions and theorems easier, but note that it can also
make [scoped instances], notations, and attributes from a different namespace available.

The `open` command can be used in a few different ways:

* `open Some.Namespace.Path1 Some.Namespace.Path2` makes all non-protected names in
  `Some.Namespace.Path1` and `Some.Namespace.Path2` available without the prefix, so that
  `Some.Namespace.Path1.x` and `Some.Namespace.Path2.y` can be referred to by writing only `x` and
  `y`.

* `open Some.Namespace.Path hiding def1 def2` opens all non-protected names in `Some.Namespace.Path`
  except `def1` and `def2`.

* `open Some.Namespace.Path (def1 def2)` only makes `Some.Namespace.Path.def1` and
  `Some.Namespace.Path.def2` available without the full prefix, so `Some.Namespace.Path.def3` would
  be unaffected.

  This works even if `def1` and `def2` are `protected`.

* `open Some.Namespace.Path renaming def1 → def1', def2 → def2'` same as `open Some.Namespace.Path
  (def1 def2)` but `def1`/`def2`'s names are changed to `def1'`/`def2'`.

  This works even if `def1` and `def2` are `protected`.

* `open scoped Some.Namespace.Path1 Some.Namespace.Path2` **only** opens [scoped instances],
  notations, and attributes from `Namespace1` and `Namespace2`; it does **not** make any other name
  available.

* `open <any of the open shapes above> in` makes the names `open`-ed visible only in the next
  command or expression.

[scoped instance]: https://lean-lang.org/theorem_proving_in_lean4/type_classes.html#scoped-instances
(Scoped instances in Theorem Proving in Lean)

Makes names from other namespaces visible without writing the namespace prefix.

Names that are made available with `open` are visible within the current `section` or `namespace`
block. This makes referring to (type) definitions and theorems easier, but note that it can also
make [scoped instances], notations, and attributes from a different namespace available.

The `open` command can be used in a few different ways:

* `open Some.Namespace.Path1 Some.Namespace.Path2` makes all non-protected names in
  `Some.Namespace.Path1` and `Some.Namespace.Path2` available without the prefix, so that
  `Some.Namespace.Path1.x` and `Some.Namespace.Path2.y` can be referred to by writing only `x` and
  `y`.

* `open Some.Namespace.Path hiding def1 def2` opens all non-protected names in `Some.Namespace.Path`
  except `def1` and `def2`.

* `open Some.Namespace.Path (def1 def2)` only makes `Some.Namespace.Path.def1` and
  `Some.Namespace.Path.def2` available without the full prefix, so `Some.Namespace.Path.def3` would
  be unaffected.

  This works even if `def1` and `def2` are `protected`.

* `open Some.Namespace.Path renaming def1 → def1', def2 → def2'` same as `open Some.Namespace.Path
  (def1 def2)` but `def1`/`def2`'s names are changed to `def1'`/`def2'`.

  This works even if `def1` and `def2` are `protected`.

* `open scoped Some.Namespace.Path1 Some.Namespace.Path2` **only** opens [scoped instances],
  notations, and attributes from `Namespace1` and `Namespace2`; it does **not** make any other name
  available.

* `open <any of the open shapes above> in` makes the names `open`-ed visible only in the next
  command or expression.

[scoped instance]: https://lean-lang.org/theorem_proving_in_lean4/type_classes.html#scoped-instances
(Scoped instances in Theorem Proving in Lean)

```lean
  def S (x : α → β → γ) (y : α → β) (z : α) : γ := x z (y z)

section
  -- open everything under `Combinator.Calculus`, *i.e.* `I`, `K` and `S`,
  -- until the section ends
  open Combinator.Calculus

end

-- open everything under `Combinator.Calculus` only for the next command (the next `theorem`, here)
open Combinator.Calculus in
theorem SKx_eq_K' : S K x = I := rfl

section
  -- open only `S` and `K` under `Combinator.Calculus`
  open Combinator.Calculus (S K)

  theorem SKxy_eq_y : S K x y = y := rfl

  -- `I` is not in scope, we have to use its full path
  theorem SKxy_eq_Iy : S K x y = Combinator.Calculus.I y := rfl
end

    renaming

      K → konstant

  #check identity
  #check konstant
end

  open Combinator.Calculus
    hiding S

  #check I
  #check K
end

    inductive MyType
```

Makes names from other namespaces visible without writing the namespace prefix.

Names that are made available with `open` are visible within the current `section` or `namespace`
block. This makes referring to (type) definitions and theorems easier, but note that it can also
make [scoped instances], notations, and attributes from a different namespace available.

The `open` command can be used in a few different ways:

* `open Some.Namespace.Path1 Some.Namespace.Path2` makes all non-protected names in
  `Some.Namespace.Path1` and `Some.Namespace.Path2` available without the prefix, so that
  `Some.Namespace.Path1.x` and `Some.Namespace.Path2.y` can be referred to by writing only `x` and
  `y`.

* `open Some.Namespace.Path hiding def1 def2` opens all non-protected names in `Some.Namespace.Path`
  except `def1` and `def2`.

* `open Some.Namespace.Path (def1 def2)` only makes `Some.Namespace.Path.def1` and
  `Some.Namespace.Path.def2` available without the full prefix, so `Some.Namespace.Path.def3` would
  be unaffected.

  This works even if `def1` and `def2` are `protected`.

* `open Some.Namespace.Path renaming def1 → def1', def2 → def2'` same as `open Some.Namespace.Path
  (def1 def2)` but `def1`/`def2`'s names are changed to `def1'`/`def2'`.

  This works even if `def1` and `def2` are `protected`.

* `open scoped Some.Namespace.Path1 Some.Namespace.Path2` **only** opens [scoped instances],
  notations, and attributes from `Namespace1` and `Namespace2`; it does **not** make any other name
  available.

* `open <any of the open shapes above> in` makes the names `open`-ed visible only in the next
  command or expression.

[scoped instance]: https://lean-lang.org/theorem_proving_in_lean4/type_classes.html#scoped-instances
(Scoped instances in Theorem Proving in Lean)

## Examples

```lean
/-- SKI combinators https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SKI_combinator_calculus -/
namespace Combinator.Calculus
  def I (a : α) : α := a
  def K (a : α) : β → α := fun _ => a
  def S (x : α → β → γ) (y : α → β) (z : α) : γ := x z (y z)
end Combinator.Calculus

section
  -- open everything under `Combinator.Calculus`, *i.e.* `I`, `K` and `S`,
  -- until the section ends
  open Combinator.Calculus

  theorem SKx_eq_K : S K x = I := rfl
end

-- open everything under `Combinator.Calculus` only for the next command (the next `theorem`, here)
open Combinator.Calculus in
theorem SKx_eq_K' : S K x = I := rfl

section
  -- open only `S` and `K` under `Combinator.Calculus`
  open Combinator.Calculus (S K)

  theorem SKxy_eq_y : S K x y = y := rfl

  -- `I` is not in scope, we have to use its full path
  theorem SKxy_eq_Iy : S K x y = Combinator.Calculus.I y := rfl
end

section
  open Combinator.Calculus
    renaming
      I → identity,
      K → konstant

  #check identity
  #check konstant
end

section
  open Combinator.Calculus
    hiding S

  #check I
  #check K
end

section
  namespace Demo
    inductive MyType
    | val

    namespace N1
      scoped infix:68 " ≋ " => BEq.beq

      scoped instance : BEq MyType where
        beq _ _ := true

      def Alias := MyType
    end N1
  end Demo

  -- bring `≋` and the instance in scope, but not `Alias`
  open scoped Demo.N1

  #check Demo.MyType.val == Demo.MyType.val
  #check Demo.MyType.val ≋ Demo.MyType.val
  -- #check Alias -- unknown identifier 'Alias'
end
```

Makes names from other namespaces visible without writing the namespace prefix.

Names that are made available with `open` are visible within the current `section` or `namespace`
block. This makes referring to (type) definitions and theorems easier, but note that it can also
make [scoped instances], notations, and attributes from a different namespace available.

The `open` command can be used in a few different ways:

* `open Some.Namespace.Path1 Some.Namespace.Path2` makes all non-protected names in
  `Some.Namespace.Path1` and `Some.Namespace.Path2` available without the prefix, so that
  `Some.Namespace.Path1.x` and `Some.Namespace.Path2.y` can be referred to by writing only `x` and
  `y`.

* `open Some.Namespace.Path hiding def1 def2` opens all non-protected names in `Some.Namespace.Path`
  except `def1` and `def2`.

* `open Some.Namespace.Path (def1 def2)` only makes `Some.Namespace.Path.def1` and
  `Some.Namespace.Path.def2` available without the full prefix, so `Some.Namespace.Path.def3` would
  be unaffected.

  This works even if `def1` and `def2` are `protected`.

  (def1 def2)` but `def1`/`def2`'s names are changed to `def1'`/`def2'`.

  This works even if `def1` and `def2` are `protected`.

* `open scoped Some.Namespace.Path1 Some.Namespace.Path2` **only** opens [scoped instances],
  notations, and attributes from `Namespace1` and `Namespace2`; it does **not** make any other name
  available.

* `open <any of the open shapes above> in` makes the names `open`-ed visible only in the next
  command or expression.

```lean

  def S (x : α → β → γ) (y : α → β) (z : α) : γ := x z (y z)
end Combinator.Calculus

section
  -- open everything under `Combinator.Calculus`, *i.e.* `I`, `K` and `S`,

  theorem SKx_eq_K : S K x = I := rfl

end

section
  open Combinator.Calculus
    renaming
      I → identity,
      K → konstant

  #check identity
  #check konstant
end

section
  open Combinator.Calculus
    hiding S

  #check I
  #check K
end

    inductive MyType

  #check Demo.MyType.val == Demo.MyType.val
  #check Demo.MyType.val ≋ Demo.MyType.val
  -- #check Alias -- unknown identifier 'Alias'
end
```

```lean
/-- SKI combinators https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SKI_combinator_calculus -/
namespace Combinator.Calculus

  def K (a : α) : β → α := fun _ => a
  def S (x : α → β → γ) (y : α → β) (z : α) : γ := x z (y z)
end Combinator.Calculus

section
  -- open everything under `Combinator.Calculus`, *i.e.* `I`, `K` and `S`,

  theorem SKx_eq_K : S K x = I := rfl
end

section
  -- open only `S` and `K` under `Combinator.Calculus`

  -- `I` is not in scope, we have to use its full path

end

section
  open Combinator.Calculus
    renaming
      I → identity,
      K → konstant

  #check identity
  #check konstant
end

section
  open Combinator.Calculus
    hiding S

  #check I
  #check K
end

section
  namespace Demo
    inductive MyType
    | val

      scoped infix:68 " ≋ " => BEq.beq

    end N1

  #check Demo.MyType.val == Demo.MyType.val
  #check Demo.MyType.val ≋ Demo.MyType.val
  -- #check Alias -- unknown identifier 'Alias'
end
```

* `open Some.Namespace.Path1 Some.Namespace.Path2` makes all non-protected names in
  `Some.Namespace.Path1` and `Some.Namespace.Path2` available without the prefix, so that
  `Some.Namespace.Path1.x` and `Some.Namespace.Path2.y` can be referred to by writing only `x` and
  `y`.

* `open Some.Namespace.Path hiding def1 def2` opens all non-protected names in `Some.Namespace.Path`
  except `def1` and `def2`.

* `open Some.Namespace.Path (def1 def2)` only makes `Some.Namespace.Path.def1` and
  `Some.Namespace.Path.def2` available without the full prefix, so `Some.Namespace.Path.def3` would
  be unaffected.

  This works even if `def1` and `def2` are `protected`.

* `open Some.Namespace.Path renaming def1 → def1', def2 → def2'` same as `open Some.Namespace.Path
  (def1 def2)` but `def1`/`def2`'s names are changed to `def1'`/`def2'`.

  This works even if `def1` and `def2` are `protected`.

* `open scoped Some.Namespace.Path1 Some.Namespace.Path2` **only** opens [scoped instances],
  notations, and attributes from `Namespace1` and `Namespace2`; it does **not** make any other name
  available.

* `open <any of the open shapes above> in` makes the names `open`-ed visible only in the next
  command or expression.

[scoped instance]: https://lean-lang.org/theorem_proving_in_lean4/type_classes.html#scoped-instances
(Scoped instances in Theorem Proving in Lean)


## Examples

```lean
/-- SKI combinators https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SKI_combinator_calculus -/
namespace Combinator.Calculus
  def I (a : α) : α := a
  def K (a : α) : β → α := fun _ => a
  def S (x : α → β → γ) (y : α → β) (z : α) : γ := x z (y z)
end Combinator.Calculus

section
  -- open everything under `Combinator.Calculus`, *i.e.* `I`, `K` and `S`,
  -- until the section ends
  open Combinator.Calculus

  theorem SKx_eq_K : S K x = I := rfl
end

-- open everything under `Combinator.Calculus` only for the next command (the next `theorem`, here)
open Combinator.Calculus in
theorem SKx_eq_K' : S K x = I := rfl

section
  -- open only `S` and `K` under `Combinator.Calculus`
  open Combinator.Calculus (S K)

  theorem SKxy_eq_y : S K x y = y := rfl

  -- `I` is not in scope, we have to use its full path
  theorem SKxy_eq_Iy : S K x y = Combinator.Calculus.I y := rfl
end

section
  open Combinator.Calculus
    renaming
      I → identity,
      K → konstant

  #check identity
  #check konstant
end

section
  open Combinator.Calculus
    hiding S

  #check I
  #check K
end

section
  namespace Demo
    inductive MyType
    | val

    namespace N1
      scoped infix:68 " ≋ " => BEq.beq

      scoped instance : BEq MyType where
        beq _ _ := true

      def Alias := MyType
    end N1
  end Demo

  -- bring `≋` and the instance in scope, but not `Alias`
  open scoped Demo.N1

  #check Demo.MyType.val == Demo.MyType.val
  #check Demo.MyType.val ≋ Demo.MyType.val
  -- #check Alias -- unknown identifier 'Alias'
end
```

Makes names from other namespaces visible without writing the namespace prefix.

Names that are made available with `open` are visible within the current `section` or `namespace`
block. This makes referring to (type) definitions and theorems easier, but note that it can also
make [scoped instances], notations, and attributes from a different namespace available.

The `open` command can be used in a few different ways:

* `open Some.Namespace.Path1 Some.Namespace.Path2` makes all non-protected names in
  `Some.Namespace.Path1` and `Some.Namespace.Path2` available without the prefix, so that
  `Some.Namespace.Path1.x` and `Some.Namespace.Path2.y` can be referred to by writing only `x` and
  `y`.

* `open Some.Namespace.Path hiding def1 def2` opens all non-protected names in `Some.Namespace.Path`
  except `def1` and `def2`.

* `open Some.Namespace.Path (def1 def2)` only makes `Some.Namespace.Path.def1` and
  `Some.Namespace.Path.def2` available without the full prefix, so `Some.Namespace.Path.def3` would
  be unaffected.

  This works even if `def1` and `def2` are `protected`.

* `open Some.Namespace.Path renaming def1 → def1', def2 → def2'` same as `open Some.Namespace.Path
  (def1 def2)` but `def1`/`def2`'s names are changed to `def1'`/`def2'`.

  This works even if `def1` and `def2` are `protected`.

* `open scoped Some.Namespace.Path1 Some.Namespace.Path2` **only** opens [scoped instances],
  notations, and attributes from `Namespace1` and `Namespace2`; it does **not** make any other name
  available.

* `open <any of the open shapes above> in` makes the names `open`-ed visible only in the next
  command or expression.

[scoped instance]: https://lean-lang.org/theorem_proving_in_lean4/type_classes.html#scoped-instances
(Scoped instances in Theorem Proving in Lean)


## Examples

```lean
/-- SKI combinators https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SKI_combinator_calculus -/
namespace Combinator.Calculus
  def I (a : α) : α := a
  def K (a : α) : β → α := fun _ => a
  def S (x : α → β → γ) (y : α → β) (z : α) : γ := x z (y z)
end Combinator.Calculus

section
  -- open everything under `Combinator.Calculus`, *i.e.* `I`, `K` and `S`,
  -- until the section ends
  open Combinator.Calculus

  theorem SKx_eq_K : S K x = I := rfl
end

-- open everything under `Combinator.Calculus` only for the next command (the next `theorem`, here)
open Combinator.Calculus in
theorem SKx_eq_K' : S K x = I := rfl

section
  -- open only `S` and `K` under `Combinator.Calculus`
  open Combinator.Calculus (S K)

  theorem SKxy_eq_y : S K x y = y := rfl

  -- `I` is not in scope, we have to use its full path
  theorem SKxy_eq_Iy : S K x y = Combinator.Calculus.I y := rfl
end

section
  open Combinator.Calculus
    renaming
      I → identity,
      K → konstant

  #check identity
  #check konstant
end

section
  open Combinator.Calculus
    hiding S

  #check I
  #check K
end

section
  namespace Demo
    inductive MyType
    | val

    namespace N1
      scoped infix:68 " ≋ " => BEq.beq

      scoped instance : BEq MyType where
        beq _ _ := true

      def Alias := MyType
    end N1
  end Demo

  -- bring `≋` and the instance in scope, but not `Alias`
  open scoped Demo.N1

  #check Demo.MyType.val == Demo.MyType.val
  #check Demo.MyType.val ≋ Demo.MyType.val
  -- #check Alias -- unknown identifier 'Alias'
end
```

Makes names from other namespaces visible without writing the namespace prefix.

Names that are made available with `open` are visible within the current `section` or `namespace`
block. This makes referring to (type) definitions and theorems easier, but note that it can also
make [scoped instances], notations, and attributes from a different namespace available.

The `open` command can be used in a few different ways:

* `open Some.Namespace.Path1 Some.Namespace.Path2` makes all non-protected names in
  `Some.Namespace.Path1` and `Some.Namespace.Path2` available without the prefix, so that
  `Some.Namespace.Path1.x` and `Some.Namespace.Path2.y` can be referred to by writing only `x` and
  `y`.

* `open Some.Namespace.Path hiding def1 def2` opens all non-protected names in `Some.Namespace.Path`
  except `def1` and `def2`.

* `open Some.Namespace.Path (def1 def2)` only makes `Some.Namespace.Path.def1` and
  `Some.Namespace.Path.def2` available without the full prefix, so `Some.Namespace.Path.def3` would
  be unaffected.

  This works even if `def1` and `def2` are `protected`.

* `open Some.Namespace.Path renaming def1 → def1', def2 → def2'` same as `open Some.Namespace.Path
  (def1 def2)` but `def1`/`def2`'s names are changed to `def1'`/`def2'`.

  This works even if `def1` and `def2` are `protected`.

* `open scoped Some.Namespace.Path1 Some.Namespace.Path2` **only** opens [scoped instances],
  notations, and attributes from `Namespace1` and `Namespace2`; it does **not** make any other name
  available.

* `open <any of the open shapes above> in` makes the names `open`-ed visible only in the next
  command or expression.

[scoped instance]: https://lean-lang.org/theorem_proving_in_lean4/type_classes.html#scoped-instances
(Scoped instances in Theorem Proving in Lean)

```lean
  end Demo

  #check Demo.MyType.val == Demo.MyType.val
  #check Demo.MyType.val ≋ Demo.MyType.val
  -- #check Alias -- unknown identifier 'Alias'
end
```

The equality relation. It has one introduction rule, `Eq.refl`.
We use `a = b` as notation for `Eq a b`.
A fundamental property of equality is that it is an equivalence relation.
```
variable (α : Type) (a b c d : α)
variable (hab : a = b) (hcb : c = b) (hcd : c = d)

example : a = d :=
  Eq.trans (Eq.trans hab (Eq.symm hcb)) hcd
```
Equality is much more than an equivalence relation, however. It has the important property that every assertion
respects the equivalence, in the sense that we can substitute equal expressions without changing the truth value.
That is, given `h1 : a = b` and `h2 : p a`, we can construct a proof for `p b` using substitution: `Eq.subst h1 h2`.
Example:
```
example (α : Type) (a b : α) (p : α → Prop)
        (h1 : a = b) (h2 : p a) : p b :=
  Eq.subst h1 h2

example (α : Type) (a b : α) (p : α → Prop)
    (h1 : a = b) (h2 : p a) : p b :=
  h1 ▸ h2
```
The triangle in the second presentation is a macro built on top of `Eq.subst` and `Eq.symm`, and you can enter it by typing `\t`.
For more information: [Equality](https://lean-lang.org/theorem_proving_in_lean4/quantifiers_and_equality.html#equality)

Set builder syntax. This can be elaborated to either a `Set` or a `Finset` depending on context.

The elaborators for this syntax are located in:
* `Data.Set.Defs` for the `Set` builder notation elaborator for syntax of the form `{x | p x}`,
  `{x : α | p x}`, `{binder x | p x}`.
* `Data.Finset.Basic` for the `Finset` builder notation elaborator for syntax of the form
  `{x ∈ s | p x}`.
* `Data.Fintype.Basic` for the `Finset` builder notation elaborator for syntax of the form
  `{x | p x}`, `{x : α | p x}`, `{x ∉ s | p x}`, `{x ≠ a | p x}`.
* `Order.LocallyFinite.Basic` for the `Finset` builder notation elaborator for syntax of the form
  `{x ≤ a | p x}`, `{x ≥ a | p x}`, `{x < a | p x}`, `{x > a | p x}`.

  - `(f · a b)` is shorthand for `fun x => f x a b`
  - `(h (· + 1) ·)` is shorthand for `fun x => h (fun y => y + 1) x`
  - also applies to other parentheses-like notations such as `(·, 1)`

***
The natural numbers, starting at zero.

This type is special-cased by both the kernel and the compiler, and overridden with an efficient
implementation. Both use a fast arbitrary-precision arithmetic library (usually
[GMP](https://gmplib.org/)); at runtime, `Nat` values that are sufficiently small are unboxed.

***
The equality relation. It has one introduction rule, `Eq.refl`.
We use `a = b` as notation for `Eq a b`.
A fundamental property of equality is that it is an equivalence relation.
```
variable (α : Type) (a b c d : α)
variable (hab : a = b) (hcb : c = b) (hcd : c = d)

example : a = d :=
  Eq.trans (Eq.trans hab (Eq.symm hcb)) hcd
```
Equality is much more than an equivalence relation, however. It has the important property that every assertion
respects the equivalence, in the sense that we can substitute equal expressions without changing the truth value.
That is, given `h1 : a = b` and `h2 : p a`, we can construct a proof for `p b` using substitution: `Eq.subst h1 h2`.
Example:
```
example (α : Type) (a b : α) (p : α → Prop)
        (h1 : a = b) (h2 : p a) : p b :=
  Eq.subst h1 h2

example (α : Type) (a b : α) (p : α → Prop)
    (h1 : a = b) (h2 : p a) : p b :=
  h1 ▸ h2
```
The triangle in the second presentation is a macro built on top of `Eq.subst` and `Eq.symm`, and you can enter it by typing `\t`.
For more information: [Equality](https://lean-lang.org/theorem_proving_in_lean4/quantifiers_and_equality.html#equality)

`by tac` constructs a term of the expected type by running the tactic(s) `tac`.

The `sorry` tactic is a temporary placeholder for an incomplete tactic proof,
closing the main goal using `exact sorry`.

This is intended for stubbing-out incomplete parts of a proof while still having a syntactically correct proof skeleton.
Lean will give a warning whenever a proof uses `sorry`, so you aren't likely to miss it,
but you can double check if a theorem depends on `sorry` by looking for `sorryAx` in the output
of the `#print axioms my_thm` command, the axiom used by the implementation of `sorry`.
